questions.text: A 40-year-old lady is undergoing treatment for post-traumatic stress disorder after she witnessed a shooting when she dropped her niece at school. During a session of psychotherapy, the therapist explains to her that reliving and re-visiting a painful experience often leads to a therapeutic release of emotions. This process can be brought about using certain drugs. Which among the following drugs are not used to bring about this?
questions.solution:
The process by which repressed material such as painful experiences or conflicts, are brought back to consciousness is called abreaction, and amphetamines and lysergic acid are no longer used in clinical practice, due to the risk of side effects and drug dependence. 

During this process, the person not only recalls but relives the experience, which is accompanied by the appropriate emotional response. This results in the patient gaining insight from the experience. 

Previously, intravenous amphetamines, ether, nitrous oxide, and lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) were used for abreaction as they lead to a marked increase in speech, facilitating the release of unconscious ideas and emotions.

Drugs used include:

  • 5% solution of sodium amobarbital (Amytal)
  • Thiopentone sodium (pentothal) infused at a rate such that respiratory depression and sleep is avoided. This is done in the presence of an anesthetist. 
  • Diazepam
  • Ketamine

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male patient underwent gastric resection surgery for a gastrointestinal malignancy. Following the gastric resection, two Portex tube drains were placed- one in the Morrison's pouch and the other in the region of the gastrojejunostomy. Identify the true statements about the suture material used for securing the drains externally.
  1. It can be used for vascular prosthesis
  2. Increased risk of infection and tissue reaction
  3. Can be used for routine skin closure
  4. Gets absorbed over 1-2 years
  5. Encapsulation in fibrous tissue over 2-3 weeks
questions.solution:
The suture material used to secure abdominal drains is silk. It is black-colored, multifilament, braided, and is derived from the cocoon of the silkworm larva.

Silk is unsuitable for use with a vascular prosthesis or in tissues requiring prolonged approximation under stress. There is an increased risk of infection and tissue reaction, so they are not used for routine skin closure. It can be used to secure drains externally. Fibrous encapsulation of the suture occurs in 2 to 3 weeks and it is absorbed slowly over 1 to 2 years.

It is shown in the image below:

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient was suspected to have a seminoma of the testis. The mass was surgically removed and the specimen was sent for histopathological analysis. Which among the following findings is most likely to be seen microscopically?

choices.text: Derivatives of all three germ layers

questions.solution:
Microscopically, seminomas show a fried egg appearance of cells. This refers to cells with clear cytoplasm and a nucleus with a prominent nucleolus.

Seminoma is the most common type of germ cell tumor (around 50% of GCTs). It is the testicular equivalent of an ovarian dysgerminoma. Immunohistochemistry is positive for KIT, OCT3/4, and placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP).

Patients usually present with painless testicular enlargement. Heaviness may be felt if the size is 2-3 times normal. Rarely, it may present with symptoms of metastatic disease.

The gross specimen shows a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis.

The histological image shows sheets of uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and central nucleus, with a prominent nucleolus (fried-egg appearance). The sheets of cells are poorly demarcated into lobules by delicate fibrous septa containing a lymphocytic infiltrate. It is shown below.

Other options:

Option B: Schiller Duval bodies are seen in yolk sac tumors, and appear as glomerulus-like structures with a central blood vessel enveloped by tumor cells in a space that is also lined by tumor cells.

Option C: Crystalloids of Reinke are seen in Leydig cell tumors. They are rod-shaped crystalloids seen in the cytoplasm of neoplastic Leydig cells.

Option D: Derivatives of all three germ layers- islands of bronchial epithelium, neural tissue, muscle, islands of cartilage, clusters of squamous epithelium, structures reminiscent of thyroid gland, bronchial or bronchiolar epithelium, and bits of the intestinal wall embedded in a fibrous or myxoid stroma may all be seen in a teratoma.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl was brought to the hospital after a history of sexual abuse. Prior to the examination, stained portions of the girl's clothing were taken for analysis. The stain was extracted using 10% hydrochloric acid, following which a reagent containing potassium iodide, iodine, and water was added to it. Identify the correct statement about the test performed.

choices.text: Dark brown crystals indicate the presence of semen
The reaction is based on presence of prostatic secretions
It is a confirmatory test for the presence of semen
It detects the presence of acid phosphatase

questions.solution:
The correct statement here is that dark brown crystals indicate the presence of semen. The test described here is the Florence test. It is used to detect seminal fluid.

The suspected seminal stain is extracted with 10% hydrochloric acid and a drop of it is placed over a slide. A coverslip is placed over it and a drop of Florence solution (potassium iodide, iodine, and water) is made to run under the coverslip. If semen is present, dark brown rhombic or needle-shaped crystals of choline iodide appear immediately. Choline originates from the seminal vesicles. 

The test is not confirmatory for the presence of semen, however, a negative reaction rules out the presence of semen. Confirmation of the presence of semen can be done only if there is presence of at least one unbroken spermatozoon, or detection of  sperms by electrophoretic LDH isoenzyme.

Other tests for Semen detection include:

  • Barberio's Test: Yellow needle-shaped crystals on addition of picric acid. Reaction is based on prostatic secretions.
  • Acid Phosphatase Test: Detects presence of acid phosphatase (from prostatic secretions) in the seminal fluid.
  • Creatine Phosphokinase: Spermatozoa contain a high level of creatinine phosphokinase, which can be detected.
  • Immunological detection of P30, MHS 5 or MAB E6

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with sudden, progressive, painless loss of vision in the right eye. There was no history of associated photopsia. On examination, the retina appeared convex and detached with no evidence of breaks. Which among the following signs is likely to be present?
questions.solution:
The case is suggestive of serous or exudative retinal detachment, and the presence of shifting fluid is a hallmark feature.

Exudative RD is characterized by the accumulation of fluid beneath the retina in the absence of a retinal break or traction. Fluid leaks outside the vessels and accumulates under the retina. RD does not occur as long as the retinal pigment epithelium is pumping the leaking fluid into the choroidal circulation. The causes include:

  • Inflammatory conditions like choroiditis, posterior scleritis
  • Choroidal tumors like melanoma
  • Toxemia of pregnancy
  • Central serous retinopathy
  • Coats disease

Patients may present with painless progressive visual field defects without photopsia. Floaters may be present if there is an associated vitritis. Clinical signs include:

  • Convex configuration of the retinal detachment, with a smooth surface
  • Detached retina is very mobile
  • Shifting fluid sign- Subretinal fluid detaches the area of the retina under which it accumulates. In the upright position, it collects under the inferior retina. But in the supine position, the inferior retina flattens, the fluid shifts posteriorly which detaches the superior retina.
  • The cause of the RD may be apparent. 
  • Leopard spots- Scattered areas of clumped subretinal pigment may be seen after the detachment has flattened.

Other options:

Options B and C: Relative afferent pupillary defect and Schaffer sign are seen in rhegmatogenous RD. Schaffer's sign refers to tobacco dust appearance in anterior vitreous with substantial vitreous blood or inflammatory cells. 

Option D- Reduced retinal mobility is seen in tractional retinal detachment.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man came with progressive difficulty in swallowing food. Barium study showed marked dilatation of the esophagus proximal to the obstruction. Further investigations reveal incomplete relaxation of the LES in response to swallowing, high resting LES pressure, and absent esophageal peristalsis. Which among the following is responsible for this?

LES- Lower esophageal sphincter
VIP- Vasoactive intestinal peptide
NO- Nitric oxide
ACh- Acetylcholine
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of achalasia cardia. In this condition, VIP and NO are decreased causing failure of the LES to relax.

Achalasia cardia is a condition in which food accumulates in the esophagus. It leads to massive dilatation as a result of increased resting LES tone and incomplete relaxation on swallowing. The myenteric plexus of the esophagus is deficient at the LES and the release of NO and VIP is decreased.

Normally, the tone of the LES is under neural control. The release of acetylcholine from vagal endings causes the intrinsic sphincter to contract, and the release of NO and VIP from interneurons causes it to relax. The crural portion of the diaphragm is innervated by the phrenic nerves. Its contraction is coordinated with respiration and contractions of the chest and abdominal muscles. Thus, the intrinsic and extrinsic sphincters operate together. This permits the orderly flow of food into the stomach and prevents reflux of gastric contents into the esophagus. 

Related Pearl: Mechanism of peristalsis

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman was referred from the ophthalmology department with an examination report that revealed the presence of multiple fine brown deposits on the corneas bilaterally. A detailed drug history revealed that she was on the drugs mentioned below. You are requested to change or stop the one(s) responsible for the pigmentary changes. Which will you choose?
  1. Chlorpromazine
  2. Haloperidol 
  3. Benzhexol 
  4. Indomethacin 
  5. Amlodipine
questions.solution:
Chlorpromazine and indomethacin (1 and 4) are known to cause pigmentary deposits in the cornea and should be stopped or changed.

The cornea, conjunctiva, and eyelids can be affected with brownish pigmentary deposits due to systemic medications such as:

  • Amiodarone
  • Indomethacin
  • Atovaquone
  • Chloroquine
  • Hydroxychloroquine
  • Phenothiazines, such as chlorpromazine and thioridazine

They deposit in the cornea in a whorl-like pattern termed cornea verticillata, and appear as fine tan or brown pigment deposits. The whorl-like pattern shows the direction in which corneal epithelial cells migrate. Occasionally, it might cause glare and surface discomfort but rarely affects the vision. The discomfort responds to topical lubricants.

 

Cornea verticillata may also be seen in Fabry disease (seen below)

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy was referred after a physician noticed yellowish discoloration of his eyes at a school health checkup. On examination, no signs of liver failure were seen, however, there was mild hepatosplenomegaly. Ultrasonography of the abdomen revealed no abnormality. Liver function tests are shown below.

Serum bilirubin 2.4 mg/dL (Unconjugated 2.2 mg/dl, Conjugated 0.2 mg/dl)
AST 32 IU/L
ALT 16 IU/L
ALP 100 IU/L
Albumin 4.2g/dl
Globulin 2.4g/dl

Identify the correct Van den Bergh reaction that will be seen in this case.

choices.text: Colour develops in the presence of methanol
Colour immediately on addition of the reagent
Colour produced immediately intensifies on addition of methanol
No colour produced on addition of the reagent

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Gilbert's syndrome, and Van den Bergh reaction gives indirect positive due to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Van den Bergh reaction is a colorimetric method to measure the serum bilirubin level. The reagent diazotized sulfanilic acid (sulfanilic acid in HCl and sodium nitrite) reacts with bilirubin to form a purple-colored complex, azobilirubin. The reactions are shown below.

Clinical condition Reaction with reagent Interpretation
Normal serum No reaction Negative
High conjugated bilirubin
eg: Obstructive jaundice		 Colour produced immediately, without the addition of alcohol Direct positive
High unconjugated bilirubin
eg: Hemolytic anemia		 Colour produced only on the addition of alcohol  Indirect positive
High conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin
eg: Hepatic jaundice		 Colour produced immediately, intensifies on the addition of alcohol Biphasic reaction
 
Gilbert’s syndrome is the most common inherited disorder of bilirubin metabolism. It is inherited as an autosomal recessive trait where there is reduced UDP-glucuronyl transferase enzyme. The plasma bilirubin is usually less than 6 mg/ dL and the LFTs are otherwise normal. There is no bilirubinuria because the hyperbilirubinemia is predominantly unconjugated. The condition is not associated with liver injury and thus has an excellent prognosis, needs no treatment.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the OPD with complaints of nasal congestion, nasal discharge, and frequent headaches for the past few weeks. During this time, he noticed increased mouth breathing, dry cough at night, and his wife told him that he started snoring. He has a history of asthma. One year ago, he had an asthma exacerbation while being treated for an ankle sprain. Two weeks ago, he had another asthma exacerbation after taking aspirin for his headaches.  Examination shows mild tenderness over the forehead bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presenting symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient with nasal congestion, watery nasal discharge, dry cough at night that is likely caused due to postnasal drip, and features of nasal obstruction suggested by mouth breathing and snoring are suggestive of nasal polyps.

The nasal polyps in this clinical vignette along with asthma and aspirin intolerance are also suggestive of aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease or AERD. This usually presents with features of the classical Samter's triad which consists of-

  • Nasal polyposis
  • Asthma
  • Aspirin intolerance.

 

 Other options:

Angiofibroma presents with a history of profuse recurrent epistaxis. It has a firm consistency and bleeds easily on probing.

Adenoid hypertrophy can cause symptoms like snoring, mouth breathing, sleep apnoea syndrome or speech abnormalities (rhinolalia clausa), recurrent rhinosinusitis, chronic otitis media with effusion associated with adenoid hyperplasia, recurrent ear discharge and dental malocclusion. It is seen in a younger population and has not been associated with aspirin sensitivity.

Bronchial asthma does not attribute to the other chronic symptoms seen in this patient like nasal discharge, or snoring.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida developed fever and pruritic vesicular rashes one day after a full-term normal vaginal delivery. A diagnosis of varicella infection was made. How should the neonate be managed?

choices.text: Acyclovir therapy should be started immediately

questions.solution:
Passive immunization with Varicella-Zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG) is administered to neonates whose mothers develop a varicella-zoster rash from five days before delivery up to two days after delivery.

If the fetus or neonate is exposed to active varicella infection just before or during delivery, they may develop a disseminated visceral and central nervous system disease, which can be fatal. Neonte is not at risk of severe neonatal chicken pox, if mother contracts infection before and after this period (i.e 5 days before and 2 days after delivery), in that case passive immunisation is not required.

VZIG may not prevent infection, but reduces the severity of neonatal infection. Monitoring of the neonate should be prolonged to 28 days, as VZIG may prolong the incubation period.

If signs of neonatal infection develop despite VZIG, the neonate should be treated with acyclovir. 

Primary varicella infection presents with flu-like symptoms, followed by a pruritic vesicular rash. The fetus may develop congenital varicella syndrome if infection occurs in the first half of pregnancy, the highest risk is between 13 and 20 weeks. Features of congenital varicella syndrome include:

  • Chorioretinitis
  • Microphthalmia
  • Cerebral cortical atrophy
  • Growth restriction
  • Hydronephrosis
  • Limb hypoplasia
  • Cicatricial skin lesions

Pregnant women who are exposed to varicella and are susceptible should be given VZIG. Infected women usually require only supportive care, but those who require intravenous (IV) fluids and or develop pneumonia should be hospitalized. Intravenous acyclovir therapy is given to women requiring hospitalization.

questions.text: A factory worker with tuberculosis was started on DOTS (directly observed treatment short course) and is advised to rest. He earns Rs 20,000/- as a monthly income and is eligible for periodic payments under the Employees State Insurance Act scheme. Which benefit does this case fall under?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient is diagnosed to have tuberculosis, and thus he is eligible for the extended sickness benefit of the ESI scheme. 

Extended sickness benefit is the leave given up to a maximum period of two years. The diseases for which extended sickness benefits are applied are TB, leprosy, empyema, HIV, malignancies, plegias, etc. During this period, 80 per cent of the wages are paid.

ESI act was amended to provide cash and medical benefits to employees during sickness, maternity, and employment injury. People with monthly earnings up to 21,000 are covered under this scheme. Cash benefits are made through branches and cash offices. The medical benefits are made available through ESI dispensaries, clinics, hospitals, etc. The benefits provided to the insured persons are:

  • Medical benefits - Complete medical care is provided to the insured person and his/ her family members.
  • Sickness benefits - include a periodic cash payment for 91 days to the insured sick person. 70% of the average daily wages is given as the daily rate if the person is under medical treatment. 
  • Enhanced sickness benefit - includes 14 days of leave given for tubectomy and 7 days of leave for vasectomy. The amount payable is equal to the full wages.
  • Maternity benefits - cash payments equal to full wages are paid to the insured person for up to 26 weeks in cases of pregnancy.
  • Disablement benefit - cash payment and free medical treatment are given for temporary or permanent disablements and occupational diseases.
  • Dependant's benefit - if an employment injury causes the death of the insured person, the dependants are eligible for periodic payments.
  • Funeral expenses of Rs 15000 are payable to the dependants.
  • Rehabilitation allowance - the insured person and the family members continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement and retirement.

Note: Directly observed treatment short course (DOTS) is an effective treatment strategy used for tuberculosis. In the intensive phase of the treatment, the patient swallows the drug in the presence of a healthcare worker. During the continuation phase, medicine is issued for a week and only the first dose is swallowed in the presence of a health worker. 

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with a history of chronic cough and wheezing. History taking reveals that he had a lower respiratory tract infection 15 months ago. After ruling out other causes, the pediatrician diagnoses this case as Swyer-James syndrome. This could be most likely due to the late sequelae of which of the following infections?
questions.solution:
Swyer–James syndrome is most likely due to late sequelae of adenovirus infection. This condition can also be due to respiratory syncytial virus, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, influenza A, or measles infections.

This condition is also called MacLeod syndrome. The infection can produce pulmonary vascular hypoplasia with subsequent hypoperfusion leading to unilateral hyperlucent lung (refers to underdevelopment of the affected lung). Clinically, children with this syndrome frequently exhibit hemoptysis, wheezing, a chronic cough, and recurrent pneumonia. During exhalation, some individuals exhibit the characteristic mediastinal shift away from the lesion. Bronchography or CT scanning can frequently show bronchiectasis.

Diagnosis is made based on the following triad of findings:

  • Unilateral hyperlucent lung- This occurs due to the trapping of expiratory air
  • Diffusely decreased ventilation in the affected lung
  • Affected lung shows decreased perfusion in angiography/ ventilation-perfusion scan

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presented with a high fever, muscle aches, and easy fatigability. He gives history of diarrhoea and abdominal pain about 6 weeks ago. Dietary history reveals consumption of raw or undercooked pork. The blood investigations showed eosinophilia. His muscle biopsy shows the following finding. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the causative organism of this disease?

choices.text: Pig acts as an intermediate host

questions.solution:
The given image shows an encysted spiral larvae in the muscle which is characteristic of Trichinella spiralis. The clinical presentation and eosinophilia further support the diagnosis. Neurocysticercosis is caused by Taenia solium ( larval stage known as Cysticercosis cellulose).

Trichinella is viviparous i.e. produces larvae. The larvae enter the intestine and invade the epithelium developing into adult. Clinical features at this stage include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. In the later phase of the infection, the larvae move from the intestines into the circulation and migrate into muscles where they are encysted. This causes symptoms like fever, myalgia, etc.

Detection of spiral larvae in muscle tissue is done by performing a muscle biopsy. Deltoid, biceps, gastrocnemius, or pectoralis muscles are usually selected for biopsy. About 1 g of muscle tissue preferably near the tendon insertion is biopsied. Safranin staining is done. 

It can be treated using albendazole along with steroids to control inflammation.

Note:

Neurocysticercosis is caused by the CNS infection with the pork "tapeworm", Taenia solium. It typically presents with seizures. Infection leads to extra-intestinal disease (including neurocysticercosis) usually occurs as a result of eating food or drinking water contaminated by human feces containing T. solium eggs.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with a history of Raynaud’s phenomenon that has worsened over the past 6 months. She noticed hard whitish bumps over her thumb, as shown in the image. She also reports joint pains involving her hands and wrists and difficulty in swallowing solid food. On examination, there is a hardening of the skin of the hands with claw-like appearance. Laboratory study reveals high titers of anticentromere antibodies. What is the most likely condition involving her hands?
questions.solution:
Calcinosis cutis is a condition in which calcium salts are deposited in the skin and subcutaneous tissue. The combination of calcinosis cutis, Raynaud's phenomenon, esophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasia, is termed CREST syndrome. This syndrome is a variant of systemic sclerosis.

Dystrophic calcification is the most common cause of calcinosis cutis and is associated with normal laboratory values of calcium and phosphorus. It may involve the skin, subcutaneous, and soft tissues and occur in about 40% of the patients, most commonly seen in patients with long-standing anti-centromere antibody-positive limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc).

The calcific deposits are composed of calcium hydroxyapatite crystals and vary in size from small punctate lesions to large masses. The deposits usually occur in tissues damaged due to inflammation, hypoxia, and local trauma. They can be visualized on plain radiography and dual-energy CT.

Calcinosis cutis is commonly seen over the finger pads, palms, extensor surfaces of the forearms, and the olecranon and prepatellar bursae. The lesions cause pain and nerve compression. They may ulcerate through the skin, cause drainage of chalky-white material, and lead to secondary infections.

Related Pearl: Manifestations of systemic sclerosis

Progressive atrophy and collagenous fibrous replacement of the muscular is most severe in the esophagus.

The lower two-thirds of the esophagus often develops a rubber-hose–like an inflexibility.

Joint destruction is not common in systemic sclerosis.

Kidneys.

The most prominent are the vascular lesions.

Interlobular arteries show intimal thickening as a result of deposition of mucinous or finely collagenous material

The lungs are involved in more than 50% of individuals

questions.text: A senior resident working in an intensive care unit has assembled the following equipment to perform a procedure. Which of the following procedures he would be performing?
questions.solution:
From the materials which have been gathered by the senior resident, it can be inferred that he would be performing a central venous catheterization.

The image below shows the equipment for performing a central venous catheterization.

The instruments are numbered as follows:

  1. A syringe with a local anesthetic
  2. Scalpel in case venous cutdown is needed
  3. Introducer needle on the syringe with saline to detect backflow of blood upon vein penetration
  4. Guidewire
  5. Tissue dilator
  6. An indwelling catheter
  7. Additional fasteners, and corresponding surgical thread

The catheter can be inserted into any of the following veins - Right and internal jugular veins, subclavian vein, external jugular veins, and femoral vein.

Indications of central venous catheterization include

  • Central venous pressure monitoring
  • Pulmonary artery catheterization and monitoring
  • Transvenous cardiac pacing
  • Temporary hemodialysis
  • Drug administration (concentrating vasoactive drugs, hyperalimentation, chemotherapy, agents irritating peripheral veins, prolonged antibiotic therapy)
  • Rapid infusion of fluids
  • Aspiration of air emboli
  • Inadequate peripheral venous access
  • Sampling site for repeated blood testing

Complications of central vein catheterization are

  • Arterial puncture - This is the most common mechanical complication. 
  • Cardiac tamponade - This is the most important life-threatening complication. It occurs as a result of puncture of intrapericardial superior vena cava, right atrium, or right ventricle.
  • Pneumothorax - This is more common in subclavian vein catheterization as a result of injury to the underlying pleura.
  • Chylothorax - This can occur particularly in left subclavian vein catheterization. But it is not the most common.
  • Injury to the associated nerves - like brachial plexus, stellate ganglion, phrenic nerve, or vocal cords.
  • Thromboembolism - This can lead to venous thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. It is more common with femoral veins.
  • Infections - most common late complication.

questions.text: A cardiac surgeon demonstrates the following recess to his juniors and explains its importance that it allows surgeons to isolate and apply a temporary aortic cross-clamping. The sinus he is referring to lies anterior to the ____.

choices.text: Superior venacava and left atrial appendage

questions.solution:
The sinus pointed out is the transverse sinus. It lies anterior to the superior vena cava and the left atrial appendage.

The reflections of the serous pericardium are arranged as two tubes – one enclosing the aorta and the pulmonary trunk and the other enclosing the vena cavae and the four pulmonary veins. 

The transverse sinus is a passage between the two 'tubes'. It lies superior to the left atrium. It lies posterior to the aorta and the pulmonary trunk and anterior to the superior vena cava and the left atrial appendage. Inferiorly it is related to the oblique sinus.

The zone of reflection surrounding the veins is J-shaped and the cul-de-sac formed within the J is the oblique pericardial sinus. This lies posterior to the left atrium

The image below shows the posterior view of the heart demonstrating the oblique and the transverse sinus.

Clinical significance:

During cardiac surgery, the transverse pericardial sinus allows a surgeon to isolate the pulmonary trunk and ascending aorta and apply a temporary ligature or clamp.

questions.text: A newborn was born with the deformity as shown in the image below. You apply a cast as per Ponseti's technique and ask them to return for complete treatment. The patient is however lost to follow-up and is brought to you 2 years later. Which of the following will you do?
questions.solution:
The image shows congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV). Since the child is less than 3 years old, posteromedial soft tissue release procedures should be done as per the agewise management protocol of CTEV.

The first line of management for CTEV is Ponseti's technique in which gradual correction of deformities is done by plaster cast. The sequence of correction is given as:

C- Cavus 

A- Adduction

V- Varus

E- Equinus

In addition to the above procedure, we can provide the child with CTEV shoes as the child has started walking to retain the correction.

Features of CTEV shoes:

  • Straight inner border prevents adduction
  • Outer shoe raise prevents foot inversion
  • Absence of heel prevents equinus
  • Used once the deformity is corrected and when the child starts walking, upto 5 years of age

Related Pearl: Age wise management of CTEV

Initial treatment starts with Ponseti's POP cast as early as possible, but within 1 year of age.

If deformity gets corrected:

  • Dennis Brown splint is used till 1 year of age
  • After 1 year upto 5 years CTEV shoes are used in day, and Dennis Brown splint is used at night

If deformity is not corrected or untreated previously:

  • 1-3 years: Posteromedial soft tissue release (PMSTR) 
  • 3-5 years: Dillwyn Evans procedure
  • 5-8 years: Dwyer osteotomy
  • 8-10 years: Wedge tarsectomy
  • >10 years: Triple arthrodesis, external fixators

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman who was operated for a femur fracture complains of shortness of breath on the fourth postoperative day. She has chest pain and tachycardia as well. Her chest X-ray is shown below. This finding is most probably suggestive of ________.
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the X-ray showing Hampton's hump is suggestive of pulmonary embolism.

Pulmonary embolism:

Pulmonary embolism refers to embolic occlusion of the pulmonary arterial system.

Most patients present with pleuritic chest pain, dyspnoea, and tachypnoea. The classical clinical triad of sudden onset of chest pain, dyspnoea, and hemoptysis is present in only a few cases.

Chest x-ray signs related to pulmonary embolism include:

  • Hampton's hump is a pleural-based, wedge-shaped opacity with the apex of the triangle pointed towards the occluding vessel or hilum and implies lung infarction. 
  • Westermark sign is a chest X-ray finding in pulmonary embolism. It is defined by a hyperlucent area with decreased vascularity due to oligemia of the involved part of the lung.
  • Chest x-ray: A large part of the right hemithorax is hypodense due to oligaemia, secondary to vasoconstriction distal to an embolus.
  • Fleishner sign: Enlarged pulmonary artery.
  • Knuckle or sausage sign, describing a dilatation of a central pulmonary artery due to occlusion by the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.
  • Palla’s sign: Dilated right descending pulmonary artery (Image below):
  • Melting sign: infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.
  • Elevated hemidiaphragm.
  • The best known indirect sign of PE on transthoracic echo is McConnell's sign. That is hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with the normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

questions.text: A professional violin player presents with well-defined plaques on his neck with comedones, lichenification, and pigmentation. The probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The lesion consistent with the given clinical history is acne mechanica, which is also known as fiddler's neck.

Acne mechanica describes acne that occurs at the site of repeated mechanical trauma and/or frictional obstruction of the pilosebaceous outlet resulting in comedone formation. Examples include fiddler’s neck, which may occur on the neck of violin players, and is characterized by well‐defined plaques with the presence of comedones, lichenification, and pigmentation.

Other Options:

Option B: Acne fulminans or acne maligna is a rare and severe destructive form of acne presenting primarily in adolescent males. It most frequently affects the trunk but can affect the face and presents acutely in association with systemic symptoms.

Option C: Acne conglobata represents a rare and severe form of acne characterized by multiple and extensive inflammatory papules, tender nodules, and abscesses that commonly coalesce to form malodorous draining sinus tracts.

Option D: Acne excoriee is regarded as a self‐inflicted skin condition in which the sufferer compulsively picks real or imagined acne lesions predominantly on the face. It is predominantly seen in adolescent girls. 

Other psychiatric disorders associated with acne are

  • A small number of patients with body dysmorphic disorder have acne as their prime symptom. The perceived acne is out of proportion to physical signs.
  • Acne has been reported in anorexia nervosa. Acne itself may be a predisposing factor for anorexia in vulnerable teenage age groups who adopt a diet in an attempt to control their acne. 

Related Pearl: Important Syndromes Related to Acne

Important Syndromes Related to Acne

I. SAPHO syndrome

  1. Synovitis
  2. Acne
  3. Pustulosis
  4. Hyperostosis
  5. Osteitis

II. HAIR-AN syndrome

  1. Hyperandrogenism (HA)
  2. Insulin Resistance (IR)
  3. Acanthosis Nigricans(AN)

III. SAHA syndrome

  1. Seborrhoea
  2. Acne
  3. Hirsutism
  4. Androgenetic alopecia

IV. PAPA syndrome

  1. Pyogenic Arthritis (PA)
  2. Pyoderma gangrenosum (P)
  3. Acne(A)

questions.text: Which of the following options is incorrect regarding ROME IV criteria?

choices.text: Recurrent abdominal pain, on average should be present for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months
Associated with a change in stool form
Associated with a change in stool frequency
Abdominal pain for the last 3 weeks with symptom onset at least 6 months before diagnosis.

questions.solution:
The ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS  must be fulfilled for the last 3 months with symptom onset at least 6 months before diagnosis.

The onset of symptoms during a period of stress or emotional upset is a feature that supports a diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

Based on bowel movement patterns, IBS is classified as:

  • IBS-C: Irritable bowel syndrome-constipation predominant
  • IBS-D: Irritable bowel syndrome-diarrhea predominant
  • IBS-M: Irritable bowel syndrome-mixed

Alteration in bowel habits (constipation/diarrhea) is the most consistent clinical feature in IBS. This means that a majority of people suffering from IBS have an alteration in bowel habits. The most common pattern is constipation alternating with diarrhea, usually with one of these symptoms predominating.

IBS is a clinical diagnosis that can be made without performing many tests if the patient presents with typical symptoms. However, it is recommended to perform the following tests in most patients to rule out other conditions:

  • Complete blood count
  • Sigmoidoscopic examination
  • Stool examination for ova and parasites
  • 3-week lactose-free diet
  • Fecal calprotectin levels help distinguish inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) from IBS

In patients >40 years, air-contrast barium enema or colonoscopy should also be performed.

Related Pearl: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

  • Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)
  • Associated with a change in stool frequency
  • Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with onset of some symptoms at least 6 months before diagnosis.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

For abdominal pain

  • Antispasmodics - Dicyclomine
  • Tricyclic antidepressants - Amitriptyline, Imipramine
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Citalopram

For diarrhoea

  • Opiate - Loperamide
  • 5-HT3 antagonist - Alosetron
  • Bile acid sequestrant - Cholestyramine resin

For constipation

  • Laxatives such as psyllium/ispaghula husk and polyethylene glycol
  • Cl- channel activator - Lubiprostone
  • Guanylate cyclase agonist - Linaclotide
  • 5-HT4 agonist - Tegaserod
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Paroxetine
